III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400. 12207 Staff responsibilities
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all of the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care. Social
service workers shall work directly with the children, their families,
and other relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service plans for the
children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster Parent reported the agency did not give a clear reason why
children were removed.
Investigation Foster Parent:
The foster parent was interviewed on 4/6/2023, after several
attempts. She reported she requested a removal of Youth A from
her home due to his behaviors of biting, hitting, and scratching
himself. She said he was also removing scabs until he bled. The
foster parent said she was not informed by the agency on the
agency policies of what needed to be reported and what did not
need to be reported to the assigned foster care worker. She said
she became very concerned when she was investigated by DHHS
and the agency for not reporting incidents on the children in her
care and when the children were removed from her home. She
reported she did not understand why the children was being
removed because the agency did not explain this process to her.
She reported that Youth A had numerous medical issues and due
to having two younger children in her home that she did not have
prior to Youth A being place in the home, she could not provide
the attention that Youth A needed. She stated she was not
provided services to assist with Youth A’s behaviors.
It was noted that the foster parents signed and dated all of
the agency policies and procedures including the parent
agency agreement on 9/15/2022.
Chief Administrator:
2

The Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed on 4/25/2023, via
video conference. She reported that Youth A was placed in the
foster home for a year and was in the process of being adopted by
the foster parents. She said Youth A was diagnosed with Solitary
kidney, DiGeorge Syndrome, Developmental Delay, Sleep Apnea,
and a Cleft Palate. The CA reported that the Foster Care Worker
attempted to contact the foster parents via their cell phones and
home phone on 03/30/2023 at 3:00 p.m. immediately upon being
advised by Ennis Center’s Risk team that the children should be
removed pending the DHHS investigation, but they did not answer
the phone. She said a voicemail was left for the foster parent to
return the call regarding an urgent matter. She said the agency
successfully contacted the foster parent on 03/30/2023 at 5:00
p.m. and informed her that the children were being temporarily
removed pending the DHHS investigation due to alleged abuse
and neglect. The children were removed on 03/30/2023 at 6:30
p.m. and the DHS 30 was emailed to the foster parent on
03/30/2023 at 6:59 p.m. She said the foster parents returned the
signed DHS 30 on 03/31/2023 in person at the Ennis Center
office.
The CA provided a timeline of services offered to the foster
parents by the agency with the assistance of the foster care
worker and the adoption worker to assist with Youth A’s
behaviors. They are as follows:
• 11/14/22 6pm-8pm Trauma Training virtual through Judson
• 11/21/22 6pm-8pm Advanced Trauma virtual through
Judson
• 6/15/22 6pm-8pm Trauma Training through virtual Judson
• 6/22/22 6pm-8pm Advanced Trauma training virtual
through Judson
• 9/21/22 6pm-8pm Trauma Training virtual through Judson
• 9/24/22 10am-2pm Caring for Children with Trauma virtual
through Ennis-Monroe
• 9/28/22 6pm-8pm Advanced Trauma Training virtual
through Judson
• 10/1/22 10am-2pm Caring for Children with Trauma Part 2
virtual through Ennis-Monroe
• 1/17/23 10am-12pm Trauma Training virtual through
Orchard
• 2/1/23 5pm-7pm Basic Mental Health virtual through
Methodist
• 2/7/23 6pm-8pm Healing through Attachment virtual
through Orchards
• 2/16/23 6pm-8pm Trauma Informed Parenting virtual
through OFS
3

• 3/20/23 6:30pm-7:30pm Child Development virtual through
RR2
• 3/21/23 6pm-8pm. Trauma Training 101 virtual through
Spectrum
• 3/29/23 6pm-8pm Trauma Training 201 virtual through
Spectrum
• 4/25/23 Training: Childhood Psychological Disorders
(virtual by Orchards)
• 4/28/23 and 4/29/23 Empower to Connect (TBRI) virtual at
Woodside Bible Church in Troy
The CA reported the foster parents also completed the following
training:
• Foster Care Support Group at Oakland Church in
Rochester, MI- 7/2/2022; 2 hours each
• Picky Eaters Training (Spaulding)- 7/28/2022; 1 hour each
Loving the Same Child- Respecting, Honoring, &
Navigating Openness with the Biological Family for the
Children you work with (Judson Center)- 8/4/2022; 2 hours
each
• NCTSN Caring for Children Who have Experienced
Trauma- Resource Parent Training- Modules 1, 2, 3, & 4
(Ennis Center for Children)- 9/24/2022; 4 hours each
• NCTSN Caring for Children Who have Experienced
Trauma- Resource Parent Training- Modules 5, 6, 7, &
8(Ennis Center for Children)- 10/1/2022; 4 hours each
• Foster Parent Support Group (Orchards Children’s
Services)- 3/23/2023; 2 hours each
• Neuroscience of Happiness (Orchards Children’s
Services)- 5/15/2023; 2 hours each
Foster Care Worker:
The foster care worker reported she was often in the home of the
foster parents more than once monthly. She said sometimes she
picked up kids for sibling visits/parenting times and answering any
questions the foster parent may have.
Documentation Reviewed:
• DHS 30 forms, Foster Parent/caregiver Notice of Move for
each child in the foster home explaining the date of removal
and the reason why. These forms were signed by the
foster parents and dated 3/30/2023.
• MiSACWIS case notes regarding training/resources
provided to the foster parents by the agency.
4

• Agency policy and procedures signed and dated by the
foster parents.
Analysis Based on interviews and documentation, there is insufficient
evidence to support the allegations; that the social service workers
did not work directly with the children, their families, and other
relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, for the children and their families.
There is sufficient evidence to support that the foster parent was
explained the reason why the children in her home was being
removed.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
Section (3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child’s
Description record before a change of placement occurs:
(a) Reason for the change in placement.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation False allegations were made against the foster parents regarding
child abuse when the foster parents requested a 30-day removal
of a child who was no longer in the home due to the child self-
harming.
Investigation Foster Parent:
After several attempts were made to contact the Foster Parent, I
interviewed her on 4/6/2023, by telephone. She reported false
allegations were made against her by the assigned adoption
worker because the adoption worker was upset with her because
she rescinded her request to adopt Youth A. She reported DHHS
came to her home and completed an investigation, and the
allegations were not substantiated. She reported the agency also
made allegations against her home and placed her on a corrective
action plan and removed the children in her home. She wanted to
know how she could reduce the length of time for the corrective
action plan (six months) so it will not interfere with her planned
adoption in the fall of a sibling group. The Foster Parent did not
take any responsibility for her own actions regarding the recent
incidents that occurred in her home regarding the well-being of the
children in her home. She admitted that she did not report all of
the incidents that occurred with Youth A because she was not
aware that she had to report every time Youth A injured himself.
She provided an example of Youth A falling in the basement
5

where he received bruises on his back. She said she did not
report this incident because she contributed it to a child bruising
himself while playing on the playground.
Chief Administrator:
The Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed on 3/29/2023. In
response to why Youth A was removed from Foster Home 1, she
reported the following: The foster care worker (FCW) received a
telephone call from the current foster care placement (Foster
Parent 2) of Youth A who reported that she had a conversation
with the previous foster care, (Foster Parent 1) who reported
disturbing information. The current foster parent (Foster Parent 2)
reported that Foster Parent 1 told her that while Youth A was
placed in her home, she was holding Youth A down and her
husband thought she was hurting Youth A and that her husband
pushed her off Youth A. Foster Parent 2 told the FCW that Youth
A was bleeding from his penis and expressed that he self-harmed
while sitting on the potty. The Chief Administrator reported that
Youth A had a well child examination on 3/23/23, and the doctor
found scars and bruises on Youth A’s back which his primary
physician stated the bruises were in unusual location to be
inflicted by self-harm. She said a DHHS report was file on Foster
Parent 1’s home after getting this information. The CA noted a
special investigation was already in progress on Foster Parents 1
home due to an incident that occurred on 3/13/2023 where Youth
B was severely burned from grabbing hot coffee from a Keurig
resulting in an overnight stay at the hospital for treatment to the
burns. She said Centralized Intake denied the complaint due to
the injuries being consistent with the report from the foster parent.
The CA reported due to it being unclear if Youth A actually self-
harmed that resulted in his penis bleeding and the unexplained
marks/bruises on his back the agency erred on the side of caution
and decided to temporarily remove the remaining children from
the home pending the outcome of the investigation.
Adoption worker:
I interviewed the adoption worker regarding the allegation of
making false statements against the foster parents due to the
foster parents rescinding their intent to adopt Youth A. The
Adoption worker denied the allegation. She reported she was
very involved during the time of the foster parent’s intent to adopt
Youth A. She reported she completed the paperwork needed for
adoption for Foster Parents 1 and during the visit the family was
excited for the adoption to be completed and signed all legal
documents. She said the following week during a foster care visit
the foster parent told the foster care worker she wanted Youth A
6

to be removed from their home as soon as possible and that she
no longer wanted to adopt him. The adoption worker said she
was informed by the foster care worker that the foster parents no
longer wanted to adopt Youth A, because her family was not
bonding with him and that she did not love Youth A. She said she
contacted the foster family to confirm the information given to her
by the FCW. She said during this time, the Foster Parent told her
that she never wanted Youth A, did not love Youth A, and wanted
him out of her home immediately. She said there was no
concerns or incidents that triggered this behavior from the foster
parent. The adoption worker said at no time did she threaten or
was angry for the foster parent rescinding her intent to adopt
Youth A. She said she was concerned about the trauma of the
removal of Youth A from the home and the lack of empathy and
understanding for Youth A by the foster parents after having him
in their home for over a year.
Foster Care Worker:
I interviewed the foster care worker and she confirmed that she
informed the adoption worker of the foster parents’ decision to
have Youth A removed from their home. She said at no time were
there any threats made towards the foster parents by her or the
adoption worker. She said there were concern about the foster
parents’ behavior towards Youth A and the incidents with the other
children that was not reported to her or the agency from the foster
parents. She said a decision was made to open a special
investigation on the home due to several incidents that had
occurred in the home regarding the children placed in her home
and their well-being. Foster Care Worker reported for the well -
being of all children, a decision was made by her upper
administration to remove all children from the home until the
investigations were completed. She said the foster parent did not
report injuries that occurred with Youth A when they occurred.
The foster care worker said when asked about Youth A’s injuries,
the foster parent reported she did not think it was an emergency
that needed to be reported. She provided an example of the
Foster Parent not reporting incidents such as the foster parent
was with a repair man for about 15 minutes, Youth A had gotten
outside and was eating dog feces or throw up. The FCW said
when she expressed this with Youth A’s Physician, she said this
information should have been reported immediately to her
attention to determine if the child ingested parasites. The Foster
Care Worker said the foster parent did not report this incident and
when the foster care worker asked the foster parent about it, she
said the foster parent stated she expected Youth A to set an
example for the younger kids in the home. Youth A is 4 years old.
7

Documents Reviewed:
• DHHS investigation report date 3/28/2023, reported safety
plans were established for the family for Youth B and Youth
C on 3/14/2023 and 3/30/2023. The family will be required
to inform workers of any incidents within a timely manner
including injuries, behaviors, etc. They will be required to
understand and follow all licensing rules, and complete any
additional training as required by foster care/licensing.
With regards to Youth A, no safety plan was needed as he
was removed from the home per the foster parents’ request
prior to the investigation. The outcome of the case was
discussed with all parties and there were no findings of
abuse/neglect.
• Agency special investigation report dated 4/24/23, reported
the foster parents were found in non-compliance with rule
414-4-b. The foster parents did not take Youth A to a
doctor when his penis was bleeding. The foster parents
provided inconsistent stories. One story reported Youth A
had pinch mark on his penis and was dripping blood and
the other story reported that the foster parents could not
find where the bleeding was coming from and that it clotted
quickly with no visible marks. The foster parents were
placed on a first provisional license with a corrective action
plan.
• Well Child Examination report for Youth A dated 3/23/2023,
reported all of Youth A’s medical needs and diagnosis.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance with this rule. Documentation
was provided to the foster parents regarding the reasons for the
removal. Interviews supported that the removal was warranted.
Notification was provided to the foster parents as to why the
children was being removed. The agency also provided
numerous resources and support to the family to assist with the
behaviors of Youth A prior to his removal which the foster parent
requested a 30-day removal. It was also observed the agency
policy and procedures signed and dated by the foster parents.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
8

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended Ennis Center for Children - Pontiac
current license status be continued.
